subject: RE: [junit] multiple assertions
msgSnippet: Ok, I m not quite understanding (or vice versa), so how about showing us some examples? Something like: public class theTest extends TestCase { private
messageBody:
Ok, I'm not quite understanding (or vice versa), so
how about showing us some examples?

Something like:

public class theTest extends TestCase {

private DataClass data;
private String name;
private String address;
private String phoneNumber;

public void setUp() {

name = "Franks, Rick";
address = "1313 MockingBird Lane";
phoneNumber = "800-999-1234";

data = new DataClass(name, address, phoneNumber);
}

public void testName() {

data.address(null);

assertNotNull("Name should not be null",
data.name());
assertEquals("Incorrect name: ", name,
data.name());

assertNull("Address may be null", data.address());
}

public void testAddress() {

data.name(null);

assertNotNull("Address should not be null",
data.address());
assertEquals("Incorrect address", address,
data.address());

assertTrue(!data.isOk());

// based on some silly assumption about
// 'data' being NOT OK if the address
// is not null and the name is null.
}
}


What is it you are trying to test?
And how do you currently have the test written so that
it does not do what you want it to do??

-Eric

--- "Hoepner, Josh (J.M.)" <jhoepner@...> wrote:
> We are automating these JUnit tests for regression
> testing. Some of the methods we are running require
> checking multiple attributes for their proper value.
> It becomes much more useful if we can identify what
> attribute asserts fail and which pass.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Eric Heikkila [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
> Sent: Friday, February 22, 2002 3:49 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] multiple assertions
>
>
> ?????
>
>
> If one assert fails, the whole thing is invalid.
> Fix what is broken, and run it again.
> Everything should pass.
>
> If you are check to make sure something is false but
> are using assertTrue, then just do assertTrue(value
> ==
> false).
>
> -Eric
>
>
> --- "Hoepner, Josh (J.M.)" <jhoepner@...>
> wrote:
> > Hello all,
> >
> > I am fairly new to JUnit and I have come across a
> > problem while writing test cases. I am in a
> > situation where I require one test case to have
> > multiple assertions. If one of these assertions
> > fails, I still need the others to run. I'm sure
> > someone else has tried something like this in the
> > past, does anyone have any suggestions?
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Josh Hoepner
> > Great Lakes Technologies Group
> >
>
